content.title: Discover the National Museum of African American History and Culture

introduction.small: Over four levels, this vast gallery tells the history and culture of the Black community in the USA.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discover the National Museum of African American History and Culture

paragraphs.text:
The Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture stayed in an embryonic stage for more than a hundred years, until it finally opened its doors in September 2016. Partly built with bronze, the structure, inspired by three-level crowns commonly found in West Africa, now stands next to the Washington Monument obelisk. Inside the building, near 40,000 items testify to a part of American history that has been severely under-represented in museums, now divided into three big themes: slavery, segregation and culture.
Serious and light-hearted topics alternate, making it possible to discover a 1918 train car with seats reserved for “coloured people”, the first Black astronaut's space suit, Harriet Tubman's silk lace and linen shawl (a former slave, she is famous for bringing other captives to safety), Afro-American theatre costumes as well as Mohamed Ali's gloves, helmet and robe.

National Museum of African American History and Culture
1400 Constitution Ave NW
Washington, DC 20560

+1 844 750 3012

www.nmaahc.si.edu

content.title: Colada Shop, Havana in the heart of Washington

introduction.small: Inspired by Cuban canteens, Colada Shop is a hybrid place, between a bar and a café, where regulars pair daiquiris and empanadas before dinner.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Colada Shop, Havana in the heart of Washington

paragraphs.text:
Its turquoise blue facade stands out amid Washington's grey buildings, and its singularity proves attractive. Inside Colada Shop, honeycombed tiles share wall space with a fresco depicting a Cuban woman. At lunchtime, high chairs and bar stools are taken by storm for lunch, consisting of some Havana-inspired snacks. For dinner, the bar is very popular with its Cuban music, cocktails, tapas and, most importantly its rooftop that comes alive when the sun sets in. Bedecked with yellow chairs leaning against a red brick wall, the colourful rooftop is a hotspot for happy hour adepts. Take a look at mixologist Juan Coronado's short cocktail selection and try – in moderation – the traditional recipe of the daiquiri. Or indulge in one of his signature drinks, like the Hotel Nacional, a subtle mix of white and dark rums, apricot liquor and purée and fresh pineapple juice. With the extra help of a few empanadas and croquetas, you will feel right at Havana.

Colada Shop
1405 T St NW
Washington, DC 20009

+1 202 332 8800

www.coladashop.com   ﻿

Menu: cocktails from 8 USD

content.title: The National Air and Space Museum, head in the cosmos

introduction.small: In Washington, take off to discover the sky and the universe at the National Air and Space Museum.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The National Air and Space Museum, head in the cosmos

paragraphs.text:
At the National Air and Space Museum, aerospace enthusiasts will be delighted while novices will also discover it with great pleasure.

Located in Washington's National Mall Park, the museum is a real goldmine. Throughout 22 galleries, learn about the history of aviation and space flight, astronomy and planetology. Thousands of objects, one more fascinating than the next, are exhibited here. Among them, admire the Wright Flyer, the Wright Brothers' first successful heavier-than-air powered aircraft as well as the Spirit of St. Louis, with which Charles Lindbergh made the first solo transatlantic flight. Even more impressive, stop in front of the Columbia, the Apollo 11 Command Module, used in the first manned lunar landing mission in 1969.
During your visit, you can also “dive” head first into the stars at the planetarium or even take flight in one of the simulators. Four experiences are offered: a flight on the Hubble Space Mission, in the open cockpit of a triplane during the First World War, aboard a futuristic spacecraft or at the controls of one of the first powered flights. Bon voyage!

National Air and Space Museum
Independence Ave at 6th Street, SW
Washington, DC 20560

+1 202 633 2214

www.airandspace.si.edu

content.title: Sleep in the elegance of Liaison Capitol Hill

introduction.small: Just steps away from the Capitol, Liaison Hotel offers a contemporary chic setting.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sleep in the elegance of Liaison Capitol Hill

paragraphs.text:
In the Capitol Hill neighbourhood, this hotel is full of charm: with beautiful decor, a restaurant that attracts everyone from Washington and, above all, a rooftop deck with a swimming pool and lounge.

In each of the 343 rooms and suites, there is a harmony of colours and materials in beige and brown tones, as well as leather and brushed stainless steel. The ensemble creates an elegant and contemporary atmosphere. Visit the hotel's common areas to be captivated by the bolder decor. In the lobby, for example, you will find a yellow wall covered in Pop Art portraits that awaken the senses.
Do not miss the largest rooftop pool in Washington. The lounge bar serves excellent cocktails that you can sip while admiring the view of the city – the Frozen Painkiller is delightful, made with rum, coconut cream, pineapple, orange and nutmeg.
In the evening, dinner at the Art & Soul restaurant is a must. Chef Douglas Alexander's cuisine is inspired by the South of the United States. Try the fried chicken leg served with asparagus, mustard, onions and shiitake mushrooms. A real treat!

The Liaison Capitol Hill
415 New Jersey Avenue NW
Washington, DC 20001

+1 202 638 1616

www.jdvhotels.com

Rooms: from 160 USD

content.title: The Dupont Circle Hotel: solid comfort in beige and white

introduction.small: The hotel has many strengths: beautiful modern rooms, a friendly welcome, and a lively restaurant.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Dupont Circle Hotel: solid comfort in beige and white

paragraphs.text:
Property of an Irish family with establishments in London and Dublin, the Dupont Circle Hotel has spacious and modern rooms with bright splashes of colour mainly raspberry red on a beige and white. If you want more personalised service, especially if you are for business, choose one of the 15 suites on the ninth floor. The terrace view is stunning.

On the ground floor, the Café Dupont serves Franco-American cuisine with organic produce from nearby farms. The atmosphere is lively, particularly in the evening. The hotel lobby serves free tea and coffee in the morning. The Dupont Circle Hotel is a good bargain, especially in this neighbourhood, which is close to the Phillips Collection.

The Dupont Circle Hotel
1500 New Hampshire Ave NW
Washington DC 20036

+1 202 483 6000

www.doylecollection.com

Rooms: from 499 USD

content.title: Hotel Monaco: a grandiose setting in a handsome old building

introduction.small: With its neoclassical rooms, this hotel will appeal to anyone looking for a mix of luxury and charm.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Monaco: a grandiose setting in a handsome old building

paragraphs.text:
This imposing building dates from 1839 and is listed as a national monument. Its historic character is fully preserved, but it is now a very comfortable hotel, blending past and modern styles. The predominantly green lobby is truly grandiose. Don't be put off by the endless corridors: the hotel is installed in four connected buildings.

The rooms are very spacious, and they are decorated with a pleasing mix of styles, colours, and materials. The bathrooms are also very large, and the tiger and zebra bathrobes are a serious plus. The American-style brasserie is a foodie favourite.

Hotel Monaco
700 F St NW
Washington DC 20004

+ 1 202 628 7177

www.monaco-dc.com

Rooms: from 229 USD

content.title: National Gallery of Art: one of the finest art collections in the world

introduction.small: Masterpieces and more masterpieces: the National Gallery of Art in Washington contains thousands. Go contemplate : they are beautiful.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: National Gallery of Art: one of the finest art collections in the world

paragraphs.text:
Many donors have bequeathed their finest paintings and sculptures to this museum. The west wing, inaugurated in 1941 by President Roosevelt, presents works dating up to the 19th century. There are wonders of Italian, Flemish, and French art, in particular four Vermeers, plus masterworks by Giotto, Botticelli, Raphael, Goya, and Fragonard. The Impressionists are in galleries 80 to 93.
The east wing, connected to the west wing by an underground hall, was designed by architect Ieoh Ming Pei (of Louvre Pyramid fame). Opened in 1978, the east wing houses modern and contemporary works, including a Calder mobile in the atrium, and, upstairs, paintings by Matisse, Kandinsky, Mondrian, and many others.
Free jazz concerts are held in the small sculpture garden every Friday night during the warmer months.

National Gallery of Art
6th & Constitution Av NW
Washington DC 20565

+ 1 202 737 4215

www.nga.gov

content.title: Arlington Cemetery: the final resting place of the fallen

introduction.small: Arlington is the most famous cemetery in the country. It is also a very pleasant promenade.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Arlington Cemetery: the final resting place of the fallen

paragraphs.text:
Here lie the remains of thousands of soldiers killed in Korea, Vietnam, Iraq, and Afghanistan. Though melancholic, a visit here is a very pleasant experience. With its rows of headstones, lawns, beautiful trees, and quiet, winding walkways, the huge estate of Robert E. Lee, confiscated in 1861 after his departure with the Confederates, has an undeniable charm.

Look for the grave and eternal flame of President John F. Kennedy. He is surrounded by his brothers, Robert Kennedy and Senator Edward Kennedy. Visit, too, the grave of the unknown soldiers, under military guard 24/7.

Arlington Cemetery
Arlington
Virginia 22211

+1 877 907 8585

www.arlingtoncemetery.mil

content.title: Rasika: the unforgettable flavours of India

introduction.small: Foodies love this award-winning restaurant, which serves phenomenally tasty modern Indian cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Rasika: the unforgettable flavours of India

paragraphs.text:
Always at or near the top of everyone's best restaurant list not just for Washington but for the entire country Rasika is the flagship of Vikram Sunderam's six-restaurant empire in the capital.

Each dish is a discovery The specialities are tawa (griddle), sigri (open barbecue), tandoori, and regional dishes. The wine list is outstanding and the staff competent and friendly. No wonder it's one of the hardest tables to get in the city.

Book early, or settle for lunch, when it is usually a bit easier to find your way inside.

Rasika
633 D St NW
Washington DC 20004

+1 202 637 1222

www.rasikarestaurant.com

Menu: around 50 USD

content.title: The Capitol, seat of US democracy

introduction.small: The heart of Washington. With its white marble, columns and dome, the Capitol is one of the best-known American symbols throughout the world.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Capitol, seat of US democracy

paragraphs.text:
At the top of the hill, the imposing Capitol, with its white columns flanked by two symmetrical wings and capped with a majestic dome, is the heart of American democracy. This is where presidents are inducted, and where members of the Senate and the House of Representatives vote on laws. A visit during a debate period is particularly interesting, provided you have booked a ticket in advance and arrive early on the appointed day. You will see the rotunda, which rises to 55 meters high, the National Statuary Hall, the Old Senate Chamber, and the crypt where George Washington and his wife would have been interred, had their families not opposed it.

The Congressional Chambers occupy the two wings of the building, the House of Representatives to the south, the Senate to the north. The Capitol is also the geographical core of Washington.

The U.S. Capitol Visitor Center
First St NE
Washington DC 20515

+1 202 226 8000

www.visitthecapitol.gov

content.title: Birch & Barley: great food and an amazing selection of beers

introduction.small: Beer, beer and more beer: the choice is astonishing.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Birch & Barley: great food and an amazing selection of beers

paragraphs.text:
Birch & Barley carries 500 beers from around the world, with 50 or so on tap at any given time. But beer is not the only specialty of this restaurant. It is also possible to have lunch there, as the food is superb, and the portions are huge.

A tasting menu is available, but tables often aren't: this is a very popular spot, especially in the evening or for Sunday brunch. Soft lighting, cosy booths and red brick walls : the décor is resolutely American and sometimes a little noisy.

Birch & Barley
1337 14th St NW
Washington DC 20005

+1 202 567 2576

www.birchandbarley.com

Menu: around 50 USD

content.title: The Phillips Collection: a dazzling collection of Impressionist art

introduction.small: At the heart of the Dupont Circle neighbourhood, the superb Phillips Collection is a big draw.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Phillips Collection: a dazzling collection of Impressionist art

paragraphs.text:
This small museum has a wonderful collection of almost 3,000 works. The Impressionist, Post-Impressionist, and Cubist paintings were collected in the 1920s by Duncan Phillips, a steelworks heir with a passion for art, who opened his home to a select public in order to show off his acquisitions.

Gradually, he expanded the collection and enlarged his house. Today, visitors flock to see the stunning works by Renoir, Cezanne, Monet, Gauguin, Picasso, and, Phillips' favourite, Bonnard.

One room is exclusively reserved for four abstract paintings by Mark Rothko, one on each wall.

The Phillips Collection
1600 21th St NW
Washington DC 20009

+1 202 387 2151

www.phillipscollection.org

content.title: The National Mall: a vast esplanade lined with museums

introduction.small: Trees, lawns, and ponds the ideal place for strolls and picnics. But the Mall is also a tourist destination for its many museums and monuments.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The National Mall: a vast esplanade lined with museums

paragraphs.text:
The long, lawn-covered Esplanade was designed by Pierre-Charles L'Enfant, who oversaw much of Washington's city planning in the late 18th century. The Capitol dominates one end, the Lincoln Memorial the other. In between, there is an impressive concentration of museums.

To appreciate the perspective of the Mall, sit on the steps of the Memorial, with your back to the huge white marble statue of the 16th president of the United States. On your left is the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, a black granite block inscribed with the names of 58,209 Americans killed during the Vietnam War. On your right is the Korean War Veterans Memorial.

At the end of the basin are the National World War II Memorial and the Wall of Freedom, which is covered with 4,000 gold stars to honour the 400,000 soldiers killed during World War II.

Lincoln Memorial
2 Lincoln Memorial Cir NW
Washington, DC 20037

+1 202 426 6841

www.nps.gov/linc/index.htm

content.title: Spy Museum: where you'll find everything you need to become a spy

introduction.small: Learn spy-craft at the world's only international spook museum.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Spy Museum: where you'll find everything you need to become a spy

paragraphs.text:
Have you always dreamed of being a spy? This is the perfect place, open since 2002, to learn the basics of your new business.

The imaginative exhibitions display the technical equipment used by intelligence services around the world. The collection, the largest in existence, is rich in miniature cameras, lipstick guns, and Bulgarian poison dart umbrellas. You'll be given a new identity not so easy to live with and go to spy school to hear the testimony of true professionals, now retired from the business. Photos and animated films complement the exhibition.

Finally, obligatory passage through the shop : where you can buy everything you'll need to start a new life.

International Spy Museum
800 F St NW
Washington DC 20004

+ 1 202 393 7798

www.spymuseum.org

content.title: Sofitel Washington DC Lafayette Square: sophisticated Franco-American atmosphere

introduction.small: This newly renovated hotel mixes history and fashion France and the United States.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sofitel Washington DC Lafayette Square: sophisticated Franco-American atmosphere

paragraphs.text:
It was already a very relaxing and enjoyable hotel, but it is even more comfortable now, after extensive renovations in 2015.

Just steps from the White House, this Sofitel Hotel & Resorts (AccorHotels group) is housed in a historic building dating from 1880. In its 237 rooms on 12 floors, it harmoniously combines history and fashion. The new décor is one part queen of chic Jackie Kennedy and one part Marie Antoinette. Choose from superior and deluxe rooms, junior suites, or go all in for the magnificent Prestige Suite. Pictures of Paris and Art Deco-inspired paintings hang in the hallways and lobby.

If you have to rise early, tea and coffee are served in the bar. Soft music and a choice of newspapers will help ease the blow.

Sofitel Washington DC Lafayette Square
806 15th Street NW
Washington DC 20005

+1 202 730 8800

www.sofitel-washington-dc.com

Rooms: from 399 USD

content.title: The Hay-Adams Hotel: overlooking the White House

introduction.small: In the city centre, this five-star hotel has retained its links to its rich cultural history.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Hay-Adams Hotel: overlooking the White House

paragraphs.text:
In this discreet, five-star luxury hotel designed in the Italian Renaissance-style, everything is impeccable. The hotel stands where John Quincy Adams, the personal secretary of Abraham Lincoln, and Henry Adams, his grandson, lived.

They were also both writers though rebuilt in the late 1920s and renovated several times, the building preserves the memory of its intellectual past. The 145 rooms, including 21 suites, beautifully appointed with antique furniture, have enormous charm. Those on the south side have a breath-taking view of the White House. The staff is very attentive and helpful, especially if you need information about the many museums and monuments in the neighbourhood, or just want to explore the surrounding streets. Don't miss the Episcopalian St John's Church nearby. Pew 54 is reserved for US presidents.

Hay-Adams Hotel
800 16th Street NW
Washington DC 20006

+1 202 638 6600

www.hayadams.com

Rooms: from 389 USD

content.title: Georgetown: Washington's trendiest area

introduction.small: With its M Street shops and restaurants, and its opulent mansions along tree-lined streets, a visit to Georgetown is a must.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Georgetown: Washington's trendiest area

paragraphs.text:
It's a neighbourhood at once elegant and bohemian, both full of nightlife and quiet. On the banks of the Potomac, Georgetown was, after independence, a thriving port where wealthy merchants lived.

Today, these opulent houses are inhabited by diplomats, politicians, and other personalities. Once you get past the fashionable shops, bars, and restaurants of M Street, you'll come across a quiet grid of streets, lined with pretty houses. Continue on via Prospect Street to Georgetown University, home of one of the nation's best college basketball teams.

Further afield, don't miss Halcyon House, Worthington House and Prospect House, witnesses of the past greatness of the city. The Old Stone House, one of the oldest buildings in the city, built in 1765 by a single craftsman, is open to visitors.

Georgetown Visitor Center
1057 Jefferson St NW
Washington DC 20007

+1 202 653 5190

www.nps.gov

content.title: The cherry blossoms: a fleeting springtime marvel

introduction.small: In the spring, for just a few days, the trees around the Washington Monument are covered with beautiful white flowers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The cherry blossoms: a fleeting springtime marvel

paragraphs.text:
During a very short period between late March and early April, the cherry trees that line the Washington Monument are in full bloom. They surround the marble obelisk that stands in the middle of the Mall, surrounded by the flags of all the states. To fully enjoy the show, after a walk alongside the Monument, take the elevator to the top, which is more than 150 metres high.

The panoramic view of the city is glorious. The cherry trees below were first planted by Helen Taft, wife of the 27th President of the United States, in 1912.

content.title: Jaleo: the best tapas in the city

introduction.small: Snack as you feel, picking among various tapas, these typically Spanish small dishes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Jaleo: the best tapas in the city

paragraphs.text:
The Washington institution that introduced tapas to local residents more than 20 years ago…

The owner and chef, José Andrés, a native of Asturias, is a star he even accompanied Barack Obama to a summit in Nairobi in 2015, where he met with African leaders. Located in the vibrant Penn Quarter, Jaleo has been adopted by a youthful, relaxed clientele that includes many tourists.

The menu offers traditional Spanish dishes, such as crispy slices of bread grated with fresh tomato, the essential gazpacho – tomato-based soup with cucumber, peppers and white bread – or the famous paella, served with rice. You can also choose among various smoked Iberian meats, and for dessert an olive oil and grapefruit ice cream or a large selection of homemade sorbets. You won't be disappointed!

Jaleo
480 7th St NW
Washington DC 20004

+1 202 628 7949

www.jaleo.com

Menu: around 55 USD

content.title: Iron Gate Inn: Mediterranean inspired, locally sourced

introduction.small: The finest cuisine from Greece and southern Italy, made with products from nearby farms.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Iron Gate Inn: Mediterranean inspired, locally sourced

paragraphs.text:
Built after the Civil War on land where a barn once stood, the Iron Gate has been famous ever since chef Anthony Chittum, previously based in the next-door town of Alexandria, reopened it in 2013. It has a solid reputation, certified by many food critics, for several reasons.

First, the chef learned his trade from some of the best in San Francisco and Washington. Second, it uses the best products from local farms. Sometimes, of course, they come from further away the fragrant Italian olive oil, for example. Chittum skilfully reinterprets the delicious flavours of Greece, Sicily, and southern Italy. In fine weather, ask for a garden table, in the shade of a vine and wisteria more than a century old. This restaurant gives off incredible charm…

Iron Gate Inn
1734 N St NW
Washington DC 20036

+1 202 524 5202

www.irongaterestaurantdc.com

Menu: around 60 USD

content.title: Ben's Chili Bowl

introduction.small: Barack Obama's favourite American lunch joint, with some of the best burgers in the country.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ben's Chili Bowl

paragraphs.text:
A cult restaurant that exudes true American popular culture, this is a place that seems immutable.

People come to Ben's Chili Bowl for the quaintly charming 1950s style decor, the musical ambience, the big smiles of the waiters and waitresses and the great prices. Ben and Virginia Ali opened in 1958, in a district known, since the beginning of the century, as the ‘Black Broadway'. Their venture has been a success ever since. It's a favourite haunt of singers and musicians Bing Crosby celebrated his 45th birthday here. Don't expect fine dining. Burgers, sandwiches, and hot dogs are the best fare.

And of course, the homemade chili con carne, the secret recipe for which has remained unchanged since the restaurant's beginnings.

Ben's Chili Bowl
1213 U St NW
Washington DC 20009

+1 202 667 0909

www.benschilibowl.com

Menu: around 15 USD

content.title: The White House: the most famous address in the US

introduction.small: It has been rebuilt over the years, modernised, refurbished, but it remains as majestic as ever.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The White House: the most famous address in the US

paragraphs.text:
Do not expect to get into one of the 132 rooms of the official residence and office of the President of the United States, unless you have made the request several months in advance. But you can still admire the Georgian white building, built between 1792 and 1800.

You might be lucky enough to spot the Presidential helicopter, Marine One, landing on the lawn. Stroll through the neighbourhood, chock-a-block with elegant residences, government offices, major institutions, art galleries, and museums. The Corcoran Gallery of Art houses the superb collection of philanthropist William W. Corcoran. It includes, among others, paintings by Mary Cassatt, John Singer Sargent, and even a 1939 Edward Hopper.

After your walk, head for a drink on the top floor of the W Hotel the view of the White House is superb.

The White House
1600, Pennsylvania Avenue NW
Washington DC 20500

+1 202 456 1111

www.whitehouse.gov

content.title: For rock and country music, Georgetown is the place

introduction.small: Political and administrative capital, Washington also knows how to have fun, as evidenced by the many clubs and bars in the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: For rock and country music, Georgetown is the place

paragraphs.text:
A rumour long suggested that Washington was boring. How wrong! Many bars and clubs do exist. The popular 9:30 Club is probably the best place in town to listen to cutting-edge rock and pop. Since opening in 1980, before moving in 1996 to larger premises, it has seen all the great names in music. Blues Alley has hosted every great blues and jazz legend, including Dizzy Gillespie.
Back in the day, Duke Ellington and Louis Armstrong played the Bohemian Caverns. You will especially find nightlife in young and hip Georgetown, the city at its most vibrant. This is where you have to venture if you care to party after a day of visits through Washington's most beautiful museums and monuments.

9:30 Club
815 V St NW
Washington DC 20001

+1 202 265 0930

www.930.com
